page.title: 04ECOLOGY WINTERBOURNE VALLEY
page.content: {Conservation} Natural habitat for num- erous species of butterfly and wild flowers. Elm trees died due to Dutch Elm disease. No oaks, but many vari- eties of woodland trees. Badgers, grey squirrels, deer, foxes, weasels, hares roam and breed. Birds of prey, migrant birds, resident birds, adders, slow- worms and grass snakes are prevalent. The rabbit is prone to myxamatosis. {Climate & Weather} Damp valley subject to frosts. During the early 1980's springs were late; there were two hot dry summers, one wet summer, two wet autumns and one winter blizzard. {Footpaths} There are 18 public foot- paths and bridleways in the area. {Pollution} Risk of fire in plantation & heathland during a drought. Winter- bourne stream polluted in 1985 by farm slurry killing food of the kingfisher.
